this is this is performance derived versus performance described you describe your performance when

44 000 organizations that are uh in this data set using circle ci to pull from
160 000 projects and that makes this about a thousand times larger than

one company and fill out something that they can skew the data in one way or another i don't think that actually
happens in those surveys because again the data analysis is very thorough and professional and they
usually can sort that kind of thing out but this is just a larger data set overall

traditionally there are four metrics that are used in devops surveys as kind of the
the indicators of high performing teams and that's your deployment frequency your recovery from failures your change

has um what's your pipeline duration and we just shorten that to duration your change failure rate which is you

failures and then meantime to recovery just becomes recovery time in our world

ci most projects are configured to run and push to upon push to a git server now this can

times per day uh okay that makes a little more sense but when you think about kind of the narrative that

all the time um and so yeah this analysis is kind of most projects are not doing

you have is deployed a lot or it could be that your single uh application your platform is

average but any one of those applications may only be changing once or twice a day

just using a little bit more ci but it's not necessarily the most significant trend
so those leveraging ci well are doing so even more so and if you had already made the investment into ci i think i think you're leaning

there are fewer developers pushing pushing code worldwide in 2020 than there were in 2019 which i think again
if you think of all the the factors going into 2020 that isn't too surprising

in the sample of of this exact sample that i pulled and so that's not a small amount um but
less than 12 seconds you think what happens in 12 seconds well it could be a number of things it could be you

something like i'm putting a a static file onto say an s3 bucket or

time out after about five hours so that's about the longest you can go but um yeah they're they're a little bit

hold in on and that's half of all builds finish in under four minutes i've seen teams that uh have an slo
around how long it takes to build their software and if things go above their slo they will stop engineering and

more diligent about flaky tests or which ones can take longer or speed up a test
and so if things take longer than four or five minutes they may throw a flag and say hey it's time to re-engineer our test suite
because what matters to us is cycle time and how fast we can give signal back to developers and so
some teams work very very hard to keep that build time under you know four or five minutes and other teams say hey 25

have been outstanding to get signal back because sometimes it was seven or eight hours and so
um you know it all depends on your perspective about what you're doing how detailed and thorough your tests are you

complete with a green status is more or less what this this metric is trying to measure

our workflows but you do see that some tests or some organizations have workflows that never fail
and so what you look at overall is the the overall success rate on average is you know it's 54 in the

year over year and if you do look at the little bit the 50th 75th and 85th percentile that

in terms of the data and that's the time a pipeline sits in a failure state
so in 2020 what we see is you know the shortest end is about two minutes and that can happen in a couple
different ways things can happen where you have a developer perhaps that pushes a config
and right away realizes they pushed an error and they re-push a config right after that it could be you have two developers and one push is a bad
config and one push is a good one and so the bad one finishes and the good one finishes and now it looks like that pipeline is recovered
um and then you can also see that some of these are way way longer in terms of recovery time if you want to capture 95 of all builds
on the system how long's the recovery time is 3.4 days which is very different than two minutes
but on average if you look at this mean at 14.85 hours what that basically tells me is
sometimes people run a build they stop their work day and they check it the next morning because that's about the

in a classic continuous delivery methodology a pipeline being read shouldn't be treated any different than

multiple contributors running in parallel um which we talked about already and
then um once you get to a certain gap you can kind of see there's this overnight waiting period

the last set of questions that i was really interested in from our data team and and from the other people that helped put this together was what can we see

so it does fall just a tiny bit at least at the 95th percentile um in duration
we see that uh you know a lot of things went up in march and april and to me the way

were on vacation that were away from the computer i guess
is probably the right way to put it that returned to the computer in march and they started working on things maybe they're adding more testing you have

success rates also increased in um you know during the pandemic as everybody
